review.title: Formal and Computational Properties of the Confidence Boost of Association Rules
review.abstract: Some existing notions of redundancy among association rules allow for a logical-style characterization and lead to irredundant bases of absolutely minimum size. One can push the intuition of redundancy further and find an intuitive notion of interest of an association rule, in terms of its "novelty" with respect to other rules. Namely: an irredundant rule is so because its confidence is higher than what the rest of the rules would suggest; then, one can ask: how much higher? We propose to measure such a sort of "novelty" through the confidence boost of a rule, which encompasses two previous similar notions (confidence width and rule blocking, of which the latter is closely related to the earlier measure "improvement"). Acting as a complement to confidence and support, the confidence boost helps to obtain small and crisp sets of mined association rules, and solves the well-known problem that, in certain cases, rules of negative correlation may pass the confidence bound. We analyze the properties of two versions of the notion of confidence boost, one of them a natural generalization of the other. We develop efficient algorithmics to filter rules according to their confidence boost, compare the concept to some similar notions in the bibliography, and describe the results of some experimentation employing the new notions on standard benchmark datasets. We describe an open-source association mining tool that embodies one of our variants of confidence boost in such a way that the data mining process does not require the user to select any value for any parameter.

metadata.title: A Formal and Computational Properties of the Confidence Boost of Association Rules

sections.text: A Formal and Computational Properties of the Confidence Boost of Association RulesJOSE 'L. BALCA ́ ZAR, Universidad de CantabriaSome existing notions of redundancy among the rules of association allow characterization in a logical style and lead to irredundant foundations of absolutely minimal size. One can further advance the intuition of redundancy and find an intuitive idea of the interest of an association rule in its "novelty" in relation to other rules. Namely, an irredundant rule is so because its confidence is higher than what the rest of the rules would suggest; then one can ask: how much higher? We propose to measure such a kind of "novelty" by increasing the confidence of a rule that includes two previous similar terms (trust width and rule blocking, the latter closely related to the previous measure of "improvement").

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Since the task of the Rule Mining Association was defined here, the problems we faced were twofold: firstly, the quantity of candidate item sets for antecedent X and consequent Y of the Association Articles X → Y are exponential with the often already large universe of elements. However, the introduction of a support threshold parameter was an important advance that is allowed for the design of efficient frequent miners and for the calculation of association sets in large datasets: the second difficulty is that the rule sets that appear "often enough" as subsets of transactions, that is, their relative frequency exceeds a certain ratio of transactions; see [Agrawal et al] and the references there. Then, the second problem is that the number of rules provided is too large, especially when we consider that their purpose is to be read and understood by a human being.

sections.heading: 2.1. Confidence Width
sections.text: Along most of the discussions in this paper, we assume that a dataset D and a support threshold are not equivalent → → Y threshold have been fixed: All our rules are assumed to be strictly above that support threshold. In accordance with the definition of redundancy in Lemma 2.4, all rules in the representative base provide some irredundant information. However, it is often the case that the representative base contains even more rules than are reasonable for human inspection. In [Balca "zar 2009], the intuition of redundancy is further advanced to gain a perspective of the novelty of association rules. An irredundant rule of a given trust c is part of the basis for this trust threshold = c: no rule of that trust or higher makes it redundant; equivalent are all rules that make it redundant to have a lower trust. Then one can ask:" how much lower? "This can be evaluated by the following definition: Definition → X"

sections.heading: 2.2. Blocking Rules
sections.text: Based on the clear, simple intuition described in many papers (e.g. [Bayardo et al. 1999; Liu et al. 1999; Padmanabhan and Tuzhilin 2000; Shah et al. 1999; Toivonen et al. 1995] to name a few, [Balca ́ zar 2009] also suggests an idea of "rule blocking," whereby a subset of the antecedent rule can be "blocked," that is, prohibits it from being made available in the issue if the trust of the rule is higher with the smaller history and the same consequence. The main question behind this option is the following: Consider an association rule X → XY, and reduce the antecedent relationship to a smaller XY. Whereas, intuitively, the rule should be subsumed with larger processes by the other, this is due to the human intuitive habit, where this is actually the case.

sections.heading: 2.3. Support Ratio
sections.text: We will relate our values of trust breadth and trust enhancement to an expression that is essentially used first, to our knowledge, in [Kryszkiewicz 2001], where no particular name was assigned to it. Along with other similar quotients, it was introduced with the term "ACM Journal Name," Vol. V, No. N, Article A, Release Date: January YYYYY. Aim to provide a faster algorithm for calculating representative rules. It turns out that this approach is efficient and useful in practice, but carries the risk of providing an incomplete output, as actual representative rules may not be adhered to. The same reference provides further analysis, including almost equally efficient alternatives, the output of which is completed. Here, we introduce this notion because it is related to all of our three parameters of trust breadth, blocking and trust enhancement, which we support; it will allow us to explain their reciprocal relationships more carefully, and allow restrictions of trust to be "pushed" into a process.

sections.heading: 3. CONFIDENCE BOOST
sections.text: This section introduces the first, simpler version of our main term; it is very similar to the one given for the trust width, but with a phrase that, although formally minuscule, is changed semantically enough to include the term blocking. Definition 3.1. The increase in confidence of an association rule X → XY (always with X-Y rule) is β (X-XY rule) = = c (X-XY rule) max. (X-XY rule) max. sections.heading: 3.1. Boost, Lift, Support Ratio, Width, and Blocking
sections.text: We present some analyses that illustrate the characteristics of the confidence boost. Firstly, we see that it is possible to filter out rules that would be discarded on the basis of the lift, because rules of the low lift result in a small increase in confidence.

sections.heading: 4. CLOSURE-BASED CONFIDENCE BOOST
sections.text: The representative rules are a minimum size basis for redundancy, defined under Lemma 2.4; however, they often constitute a large group. Before adopting the option of information loss in a quantifiable way, as we do via confidence enhancement, one could consider the option of using stronger terms of redundancy. Several previous papers, e.g.: [Luxenburger 1991; Pasquier et al. 2005; Zaki 2004], propose to treat the implications, which allow a complete basis for more compact foundations, separately from the partial provisions of trust.] In addition to another more complicated alternative, we follow this proposal as well and employ an idea of closure-based redundancy, which can also provide a complete basis for demonstrably minimal size, denoted B?. This option has clear advantages: while it offers bases that are comparable in size, and often significantly smaller than the set of representative rules, it has the desirable property that the proportion of refuses to share associations (of trust) below 1.

sections.heading: 4.1. Double-Threshold Confidence Revisited
sections.text: Next, we develop an algorithm to calculate a confidence increase based on closure. We just need to make a number of adjustments to the number that is given for a clear increase in confidence: first, we need to examine the rules of the B? basis for trust, rather than the representative rules for that trust, as this is the appropriate basis for a redundancy based on closure; and second, we need to consider the closure operator when checking whether a specific B? rule can essentially lead to a low increase in the input basis. sections.text: Theorem 4.14 leads to an alternative algorithm to filter rules from the B? base according to their closed confidence increase; we present it as an algorithm 3. Its correctness is directly derived from Theorem 4.14. This algorithm is part of the one in Section 6; ACM Journal Name, Vol. V, No. N, Article A, Release Date: January YYYY.it tends to be better than the previous one when the left sides tend to be small. It pays the price of traversing all closed subsets of a given closed sentence, but saves exceeding the alternative base with lower confidence. In our implementation, the support ratio test, as described below, is actually pushed into closure, so that it becomes unnecessary to repeat it at the time of rule assessment. sections.heading: 5. EMPIRICAL VALIDATION
sections.text: This section describes the results of several empirical applications of the term confidence boost; the next section describes a complete tool that uses lock-based confidence boost, and the characteristics we have developed to offer parameterless association mining. With regard to certain datasets, we first report on objective numbers: number of rules that exceed relatively light confidence threshold values for three datasets, all of which consist of real data but have very different characteristics. Afterwards, we briefly discuss the much more difficult and subjective question of whether the rules we find are actually the rules that one might wish for.

sections.heading: 5.1. Quantitative Evaluation
sections.text: Dataset Adult is the training part of the UCI Adult US Census Dataset [Asuncion and Newman 2007]. Dataset Retail was downloaded from the FIMI repository and contains typical basket data (http: / / fimi.cs.helsinki.fi /); and Dataset Now (based on the Neogenes of the Old World Dataset, public release 030710 [Fortelius 2003]) is a transactional version of a paleontological dataset from Europe: We slightly load and process public data 030710.xls, so that each paleontological page was poured into a transaction in which the positions were found in fossil remains. Additional information such as the name or geographical location of the website were omitted.

sections.heading: 7. DISCUSSION
sections.text: This year, it will be ready to leave the country in which it is located.

sections.heading: 7.1. Comparisons to Related Work
sections.text: We point to [Geng and Hamilton 2006] for an excellent overview of many options for obtaining support for the left and right sides of the association rules in order to construct indicators of interest, many of which work on only a single rule, with no reference to alternative rules with, say, smaller but otherwise arbitrary left sides. A noteworthy case is the elevator, which implicitly refers to a rule with the same right side and an empty left side as discussed in the Proposition 3.4 evidence. Compared to this family of measures, confidence boost is finer, as it can distinguish between many alternative antecedents in order to compare the price of being, which is potentially more costly to evaluate due to the search for smaller but arbitrary left sides, and larger but arbitrary right sides. We have shown several algorithms that attempt to circumscribe this search for smaller spaces.More sophisticated measures of interest are possible, for example, those that are based on the disparity between the jargon and the probability given by the rule.

sections.heading: 7.2. Minimum Antecedent and Maximum Consequent
sections.text: Many papers point to further concepts of redundancy, in most cases based on mere intuition. The fact that a rule X → XY in relation to X → XY is "redundant if Y" (in the sense that it has at least the same trust threshold) is actually shown in many places (e.g. [Aggarwal and Yu 2001; Kryszkiewicz 1998b; Phan-Luong 2001; Shah et al. 1999]). Our starting point is the representative basis on which we would keep X "XY" only if its trust threshold is higher than that of X "XY," by a factor indicated by the increase in trust; this quantification is an effective refinement of this well-known proposal. On the other hand, redundancy of X "XY" in relation to X "X" X "Y" Y "is debatable.

sections.heading: 7.3. Further Work
sections.text: Of course, the use of trust incentives does not preclude a combination with Lift or other measures of the intensity of implications; the extent to which these separate measures interact with trust incentives, and which of them work best, is one of many open lines of future research. In fact, any method proposed to reduce an association's output is dubious: Are these rules what you really want? We plan to continue working on this rather subjective problem, and intend to use further actual end-user evaluations from dataset providers, as we have begun to do in terms of partial aspects. We are working on datasets that come from an e-learning platform for which we have a manually recorded mark of interest for each rule provided by the dataset vendors, namely the dataset teachers who are also available for advice.

referenceMentions.context: The introduction of a support threshold parameter was a key advance that allowed for the design of efficient frequent set miners and for the computation of association rules in large datasets: there, exploration is limited to those itemsets that appear “often enough” as subsets of the transactions, that is, their relative frequency exceeds a certain ratio of the transactions; see [Agrawal et al. 1996] and the references there.

The proposal in [Agrawal et al. 1996] (and already in the early [Luxenburger 1991] where, however, the support bound proposal does not appear) is to impose upon association rules X → Y a confidence constraint, that is, a threshold on the conditional probability of Y conditioned to X.

But even taking redundancies into account, the results are, in many cases, unsatisfactory; therefore, many alternative quality measures exist for association rules, essentially due to the facts that, first, the confidence of a rule X → Y can be high even in cases where the actual correlation between X and Y is negative, and, second, it is often extremely difficult to settle for thresholds where interesting rules are kept but the total amount of rules can be handled; see [Geng and Hamilton 2006; Lenca et al. 2008; Tan et al. 2004] and their references for information about the rich research area opened up by these difficulties.

However, as one very partial and probably insufficient, but necessary action, we claim that, as a minimum, each rule should be evaluated for novelty by comparison with the rest of the rules mined, treated as “alternative” mechanism [Balcázar 2009].

Otherwise, it would not be novel, the simpler rule should be preferred, and even the complex rule discarded (or blocked), all depending on thresholds on confidence and on some other parameter such as improvement [Bayardo et al. 1999], blocking factor, or confidence boost (to be introduced here).

It was empirically demonstrated in [Balcázar 2009] that better results were obtained using both a confidence width threshold and a blocking threshold, than using a single one of these filters (or none).

Thus, our contribution here is a new attempt at formalizing the notion of novelty, the confidence boost, similar in its syntactic definition to confidence width, but different in its semantics, which is more restrictive; its main feature is that it encompasses at once both the bound on the confidence width and the ability to detect that a rule would be blocked, so that the confidence boost bound embodies both of the bounds proposed in [Balcázar 2009], yet it is computable with reasonable efficiency.

Three short extended abstracts of three, six, and seven pages respectively have announced results from this paper in scientific meetings; reference [Balcázar 2010b] contains the definition of confidence boost, fragments of Section 2 (where we also review a small number of necessary facts from [Balcázar 2010c]), part of Section 3 (the definition of confidence boost), and the algorithm in Subsection 3.

For a fixed confidence threshold, those rules that reach it, and are not made redundant by other rules also above the threshold, form the representative (or essential) rule basis for that confidence threshold [Aggarwal and Yu 2001; Kryszkiewicz 1998b; Phan-Luong 2001]; that is, every rule that reaches the confidence threshold is either in the corresponding representative basis, or made redundant by a rule in the basis.

Here, however, instead of looking for experts on a given dataset, we use a dataset for which some readers of this paper might be expected to be reasonably knowledgeable: in the same vein as the evaluations in [Gallo et al. 2007], we employ the titles, topics, and abstracts of all the reports submitted to the e-prints repository of the Pascal Network of Excellence along its early years of existence.

By way of comparison, at the same level of support, at the most demanding possible level of confidence (100%), with the less redundant basis computation currently known (the Guigues-Duquenne basis, [Guigues and Duquenne 1986]), the result is 44 rules, with considerably more “intuitive redundancy” and less interest overall, and requires somewhat longer time to be computed.

This idea is reminiscent of the decreasing support in the version of “apriori” implemented in the Weka tool [Witten and Frank 2005], but in that well-known system the user still has to provide a maximum and a minimum values to try the support threshold, and a “delta” by which the support keeps decreasing; then, the “apriori” algorithm is run repeatedly for the corresponding sequence of support thresholds.

This does not mean that it has to be replaced as a measure of intensity of implication, and, in fact, it has been observed and argued that (at least in somewhat sparse transactional datasets) the combination of support and confidence is already very good at discarding rules that are present only as statistical artifacts and do not really correspond to correlations in the phenomenon at the origin of the dataset [Megiddo and Srikant 1998]; instead, we consider that our message is that it should be complemented with relative confidence thresholds that assess the novelty of each rule by comparison with the confidence of logically (or intuitively) stronger rules.
We refer to [Geng and Hamilton 2006] for an excellent survey of many options to relate supports of left and right hand sides of association rules to construct indicators of interestingness.

More sophisticated interestingness measures are possible, for instance those based on the KL-divergence between probability distributions induced with and without the given rule [Jaroszewicz and Simovici 2002]: the induced distributions satisfy the supports of the rule and of its antecedent but otherwise maximize the entropy.

The notions of confidence width and rule blocking from [Balcázar 2009] are similar to the “pruning” proposal from [Liu et al.

The notions of confidence width and rule blocking from [Balcázar 2009] are similar to the “pruning” proposal from [Liu et al. 1999], in that the intuition is the same; also our proposal here follows an analogous intuitive path.

Major differences are that, in the proposals we discuss, a large portion of the pruning becomes unnecessary because we work on minimum-size bases, namely representative rules, and, more importantly, that the pruning in [Liu et al. 1999] is based on the χ statistic, whereas we will look instead into the confidence thresholds that would make the rule “redundant”, either in a “formal logic” sense or in a more intuitive, but still logical-style relaxation.
Our notions are also similar to the notion of improvement, proposed in [Bayardo et al. 1999] and also discussed in [Liu et al.

1999] and also discussed in [Liu et al. 1999; Webb 2007]; but improvement is a measure of an absolute, additive confidence increase, with no reference to representative rules or redundancy, and it only allows for varying the antecedent into a smaller one, keeping the same consequent.

All these proposals may make sense as heuristics, and their connection to confidence boost is developed below; however, if taken as redundancy statements then they are incorrect and, in some cases, where a precise mathematical statement and its proof are provided (like [Scheffer 2005]), the proof can be seen to switch into a “full implication” meaning of the “arrow” connective, and is actually wrong, therefore, since it does not apply to partial rules.
As a representative of these proposals, we chose to discuss the approach of [Kryszkiewicz 1998c] which can be casted as follows:

Let us point out that these rules are subtly different from the min-max approximate basis of [Pasquier et al. 2005], given in Definition 2.

First, since we mine frequent closures in descending support, instead of ascending, some of the optimizations in ChARM require further work before being readily applicable; also, the best algorithm in [Baixeries et al. 2009] (namely iPred) to compute Hasse edges is not applied, as it assumes a cardinality-ordered traversal of the closed sets instead of a support-oriented one; the theorems that guarantee its applicability have been obtained only recently, and a forthcoming version of yacaree will sport this faster algorithm, iPred.

metadata.abstractText: Some existing notions of redundancy among association rules allow for a logical-style characterization and lead to irredundant bases of absolutely minimum size. One can push the intuition of redundancy further and find an intuitive notion of interest of an association rule, in terms of its “novelty” with respect to other rules. Namely: an irredundant rule is so because its confidence is higher than what the rest of the rules would suggest; then, one can ask: how much higher? We propose to measure such a sort of “novelty” through the confidence boost of a rule, which encompasses two previous similar notions (confidence width and rule blocking, of which the latter is closely related to the earlier measure “improvement”). Acting as a complement to confidence and support, the confidence boost helps to obtain small and crisp sets of mined association rules, and solves the well-known problem that, in certain cases, rules of negative correlation may pass the confidence bound. We analyze the properties of two versions of the notion of confidence boost, one of them a natural generalization of the other. We develop efficient algorithmics to filter rules according to their confidence boost, compare the concept to some similar notions in the bibliography, and describe the results of some experimentation employing the new notions on standard benchmark datasets. We describe an open-source association mining tool that embodies one of our variants of confidence boost in such a way that the data mining process does not require the user to select any value for any parameter.
metadata.creator: TeX
